div.sent: This condition is called blindness.
Prevention: As already mentioned, besides senility or aging, there are other causes of blindness.
Some children develop cataract at birth or during their early life.
Whatever the reason, there are no specific preventive measures.
There is only treatment.
Till today no medicine has been discovered that can cure blindness.
Treatment: In the early stages some of the blurred vision can be corrected by the use of spectacles or external lens.
When the condition has progressed, then only operative means can bring back vision.
Currently, the cataract lens is removed by surgical means and is replaced by an artificial lens, and so the patient's vision is completely restored.
Reasons: The major reason for blindness in Bangladesh is cataract of the lens, where the lens becomes opaque and does not allow light to pass.
There are many reasons for cataract, but the major reason is senility.
Besides, injury to eye, diabetes mellitus, birth defects, any disease of the interior of the eye, and radiation may cause cataract.
Complete blindness may occur.
In the past many people would with white stick lose their sight due to small pox.
Malnutrition due to diarrhoea and deficiency of vitamin A may cause blindness too.
Night blindness is another form of blindness that occurs due to deficiency of vitamin A, and is seen frequently among children.
These days it is possible to do away with blindness due to cataract.
All medical college hospitals in Bangladesh have eye or ophthalmology departments.
Eye specialists are available to give advice at district level hospitals too.
Without spending much money, cataract operation may be done at the eye camps, as these camps are open to all.
At times many people suffer from conjunctivitis.
So, it is important to know how to prevent the condition, and if afflicted how to cure it.
The inner side of the eyelid and the outer exposed part of the eyeball is covered by a thin membrane, the conjunctiva.
When the conjunctiva is infected, the condition is called conjunctivitis.
Inflammation of the conjunctiva may occur due to many reasons, but the major reason is infection by bacteria and viruses, or due to allergy.
Besides, there are some cause specific symptoms and signs that are mentioned below.
Bacterial Conjunctivitis: Infection of the conjunctiva of eye may oftenoccur due to bacteria.
Symptoms and Signs: Besides the above symptoms, the additional symptom in bacterial infection of the eye is the purulent discharge.
The discharge of pus in bacterial conjunctivitis is so much that the two eyelids stick together.
Delayed treatment may lead to ulceration of cornea.
Viral Conjunctivitis: Virus may cause infection of the conjunctiva too.
Symptoms and Signs: The usual symptoms are redness of eye, first one then both; pricking sensation; watering; slight swelling; and sticky discharge.
Treatment: Anyone suffering from viral conjunctivitis must stay away from others.
Articles of use like handkerchief and towel should not be used by anyone else.
Eyes should be cleaned with cotton soaked in clean warm water.
Application of medication as per physician's advice is must.
If necessary, medicine may have to be taken orally.
Medications used by quacks like snail-water, leaf extract, rose-water must not be used.
Allergic Conjunctivitis: Inflammation of the conjunctiva may occur due to allergens.
Allergy may occur due to the application of eyebrow pencils, mascara, surma and kajol.
Treatment: Eyes may be washed with clean water, and physician's advice may be sought.
Cancer is a life threatening disease.
Among the top incurable diseases of the world, cancer is just behind Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS).
Till today, no total cure for cancer has been discovered or invented.
The exact cause of cancer is still unknown to the health scientists.
Cancer may occur in different parts of the body.
Lungs, kidney, stomach, tongue, breast are seen to be affected by cancer.
Unhealed ulcer and tumour may turn into cancer.
The cancer cells are different in that they multiply rapidly and use up the body's nutrition.
In later stages, the cancer cells from one organ spread to other organs of the body.
In leukaemia, a form of cancer, the number of white blood cells increases to very high levels.
These then destroy the red blood cells.
Treatment: Till today, no satisfactory treatment for cancer has been discovered.
Usually, chemotherapy, radiotherapy and surgical interventions are initiated either as individual or combination therapy.
There are some ways by which cancer may be prevented.
Prevention: Experts consider that smoking, excess intake of alcohol, excess intake of fatty food are contributing factors for cancer.
Side by side, intake of less fibre food, that is, vegetables, and less exercise increases the possibility of occurrence of cancer.
Experts consider that the chance of developing cancer is reduced by 30 percent if only smoking and intake of tobacco is given up.
In 1981, two British scientists'Richard Hall and Richard Petro'informed that through optimum intake of vegetables, mortality due to cancer can be reduced by 33 times.
Professor Troll and other cancer experts of American Cancer Institute, University of New York have disclosed that different vegetables can prevent different cancers.
Cancer of pancreas: Eating tomatoes, watermelons, lemons, oranges, shaddocks and so on can prevent cancer of pancreas.
Cancer of kidney and urinary bladder: Soya beans, beans, peas, lentils, and other kinds of beans can prevent cancer of kidney and urinary bladder.
Breast and brain cancer: Cabbages have a compound Xenisten which helps to prevent cancer of breast, prostate and brain.
In conclusion it may be said that, though there is no specific treatment, there are ways to prevent cancer.
Therefore, the daily diet of a person should contain the above mentioned vegetables and fruits.
Within the pancreas are ductless glands called islets of Langerhan.
These glands secrete the hormone insulin.
This hormone regulates the metabolism of carbohydrates.
The kidney in turn has to excrete the excess glucose, so the urine contains glucose too.
This condition is called diabetes mellitus.
If the fasting serum level of glucose is more than 7.8 millimoles per litre (mmol./L),
or if the serum glucose level two hours after meal is above 11.1 mmol./L then the condition is diagnosed as diabetes mellitus.
The disease is usually genetically transmitted, or occurs under the influence of the environment.
Diabetes mellitus is not an infectious or contagious disease.
Symptoms and Signs: One or more of the following symptoms and signs may be found in a patient suffering from diabetes mellitus.
Risk of Developing Diabetes Mellitus: Anyone at anytime may suffer from diabetes mellitus, but the following persons have a greater risk of developing the disease.
If a close family member, like parent or sibling, is suffering from diabetes mellitus then there is a greater chance of developing the disease.
Overweight or obese persons have greater chance of developing diabetes mellitus.
People who are sedentary workers, that is do not work much physically or exercise regularly, have a chance to develop diabetes mellitus.
Treatment: Diabetes mellitus cannot be totally cured, but can be kept under control.
There are three basic lines of treatment.
In about 60 percent of the newly diagnosed cases, discipline and dietary restrictions help to keep the condition under control.
About 20 percent of the patients require dietary restrictions and intake of oral medications to keep the blood glucose level within normal limits.
In about another 20 percent cases, dietary restrictions along with injectable insulin is required to keep the conditions normal.
So the measures for the control of diabetes mellitus is 3D's.
That is, discipline, diet, and drug.
Discipline: This is the basic action.
A diabetic patient has to be disciplined in every activity in life.
Besides, attention has to be given to regular intake of adequate quantity of balanced diet, regular exercise, cleanliness, and care of foot and nails.
Regular checking of urinary glucose, and consulting physician if any problem arises.
Diet: Adequate and balanced diet should be taken, and sweet items should be avoided.
Drug: On physician's advice, oral drugs or injectable insulin should be taken regularly.
Most people are acquainted with the term jaundice.
Jaundice is not a disease it is a symptom only.
The presence of bilirubin in the blood causes yellow colouration of the skin, sclera and urine.
This condition is known as jaundice.
Of the infections, infection by hepatitis B virus is more dangerous.
These infections cause hepatocellular jaundice.
Treatment: There is no specific drug to cure jaundice.
Patients can be treated at home.
Complete rest is essential for the management of the condition.
Paracetamol or sedatives should not be given to the patient without consulting a physician.
Fatty food should not be given to the patient, rather a balanced diet with sufficient protein and carbohydrate, and fruit juice may be given.
These days, experts do not prescribe glucose water or sugarcane juice.
In obstructive jaundice, surgical intervention may be needed.
Prevention: Hepatitis A virus spreads through food and faeces.
So, sanitary disposal of faeces, together with frequent hand washing with soap may prevent hepatitis A virus infection.
Hepatitis B virus spreads through sexual contact with infected person, sharing of needles with infected person, and transfusion of infected blood.
There is no particular definition of high blood pressure; generally it is the pressure that is higher than what is normal for a particular age.
Blood pressure may rise up to 200/120 mm of Hg, when it is considered a medical emergency.
Complication: In high blood pressure there can be damage to three important organs of the body'heart, brain and kidney.
If the blood pressure is not regulated, it may cause heart attack, brain stroke leading to paralysis, and kidney failure.
Besides, the eye may be seriously affected.
Causes of Hypertension: To the specialists of medicine the exact reason for raised blood pressure is unclear.
In about 90 percent cases, the reason is unknown and is termed by specialists as primary or essential hypertension.
In about 10 percent cases the reason can be identified, and in most cases it is due to kidney causes.
Other glands may also be responsible.
The blood pressure may be raised during pregnancy.
Prevention: The following measures may be taken to keep the blood pressure within normal limits.
Early detection and treatment of hypertension should be done, or else there may be paralysis, or failure of heart and/or kidney.
Regular measured amount of exercise must be done together with taking of a measured balanced diet.
Giving up of smoking, and stopping of taking fatty diet may help avoid hypertension.
Regular check-up of blood pressure under physician's supervision.
Active treatment helps to reduce the blood pressure and saves the patient from paralysis, and heart and kidney diseases.
Must not take or give up medications without physician's advice.
Foods like marine fish, fowl meat, white part of egg, fat free milk, and lentil should be included in the daily diet.
AIDS is the one of the most dangerous diseases of the world by which a large number of people are being infected today.
First AIDS patient was found in Newyork and California of USA.
There are remedies and treatment for different diseases, but till today no medicine is available to cure AIDS completely.
So the ultimate result of AIDS is sure death.
AIDS disease is caused in human body by the attack of one kind of virus named HIV- Human Immunodeficiency Virus.
It is one kind Retro Virus (Picture).
Which enters in human body through some specific ways and destroys the defence or immune system.
So, it is called AIDS (Acquired I mmune Deficiency Syndrome).
The last stage of the HIV infection is AIDS.
AIDS infected person is easily attacked by other diseases such as Pneumonia, Tuberculosis, Diarrhoea etc.
There is no effective treatment of this silent killer disease.
Its ultimate fate is death.
The virus is round shaped and its pin headed upper portion having the glyco protein materials.
In side the round shape hexagonal capside RNA and Reverse transcrepts are located.
The following ways are the usual modes of transmission of the disease.
Transmission of blood from HIV infected person and through the use of instruments used in medical operation.
Transmission of blood from a HIV infected person to a healthy person may transmit the disease.
Use of needle, syringe or other medical/surgical operation related instruments.
Transplacement of HIV infected organ or tissue in the body of a healthy person.
Unethical and unprotected physical relation of human being.
A newborn baby of HIV infected mother may also be infected during pregnancy, delivery or breastfeeding time.
Loose motion or diarrhoea for more than two months.
Fungal infection of different parts of the body.
Swelling of lymph glands.
More than one symptom may be found in the body of on AIDS infected person.
It may be mentioned here that if these sort of symptoms are found it may not be only for AIDS.
Generally sexual diseases are those diseases which is spread through unethical immoral relationship between male and female partners.
As for example- Gonorrhoea, Syphilis, Genital herpes etc.
It is important to note that the people, already having sexual diseases have possibility of HIV infection higher than the people without any sexual disease.
So far there is no known treatment for AIDS.
There is no effective medicine discovered in the world.
The only method of safety is utmost careful living.
Following are the main preventive measures against AIDS.
Our daily activities of life.
Should be maintained according to the social values and religious bindings.
If in any emergency case blood transfusion is needed then previous examination of the blood to be taken must be performed.
Every time new needle and syringe should be used.
Before any surgical operation/intervention all the instruments must be properly sterilized or disinfected.
Before taking any children or before conception an HIV infected mother should consult and act according to the suggestions of an experienced Doctor.
Physical relationship among male and female should be established on the basis of faithfullness, legality and protection to ensure safety against AIDS.
The catastrophic result of HIV and AIDS should be circulated though media and other means to develop awareness amongst the mass people.
To control and resist the AIDS and HIV everybody should be very much confident and strong minded.

We must be very positive and strong minded.

But still it is limited and not that much common among the general people.
Through use of same needle and syringe among the drug addicted people HIV infection spreading rate is very high and reached is at epidemic stage.

Under this circumstance we will have to be very careful right now and follow the prevention rules of HIV very strictly and properly.

Other wise within very sort time HIV prevalence rate will be very high and control procedure may become very difficult.
But it is the abuse or misuse of the addictive substance that is of concern.
The commonly used addictive substances in Bangladesh are ganja, bhang, charas, affim, morphine, heroin, cocaine, and alcohol.
Besides, products prepared from cocaine and affim such as pethedine, thirain, codeine, barbiturate and lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) are also used as addictive substance.
Methadone and diazepam are also addictive substances.
Drug abuse is the self administration of a drug for non-medical reason.
This may be in quantities and frequencies which may impair an individual's ability to function effectively.
Drug abuse may also result in social, physical or emotional harm.
Frequent intake of addictive drugs may lead to drug dependence.
Drug dependence a psychic or physical state that results from the interaction between a drug and the body.
This interaction is characterised by some behavioural response.
The behavioural response may be manifested as a compulsion to take the drug on a continuous or periodic basis in order to experience its effects.
Sometimes such drugs are taken to avoid the discomfort of its absence in the body.
A person may be dependent on more than one drug.
Reason: There are many reasons for drug addiction in humans.
The reasons for addiction can be considered from environmental, social, mental, and drug related perspectives.
Mental: Features like excitement, severe depression, aggressive behaviour, uncoordinated behaviour, and suicidal tendency may be observed.
Social: Disinterest in life and work, familial disharmony, tendency to commit crimes, and generally considered as a socially disliked person.
Control and Prevention: Some measures may help one to get out of addiction.
There are four regional offices at Dhaka, Chittagong, Rajshahi, and Khulna to work towards reducing abuse of drugs in the country.
The major contributions of the organisation are given below.
To stop abuse and illegal trafficking of drugs the Narcotic Control Law of 1990 was introduced.
This has the provision of punishment for the abusers and traffickers in different forms.
Under the Directorate there are treatment and rehabilitation centres for drug addicts at Dhaka, Chittagong, Rajshahi, and Khulna.
The centre at Dhaka has both indoor and outdoor treatment facilities, while the other three have only outdoor service facilities.
Till recent past, about 1,500 persons have been treated at these centres.
